Questions.question: Which of these is a feature in fertillization?
options: Cortical granule enzymes digest zona pellucida
Decondensation of female chromosomes
Release of hyaluronic acid
Meiosis I is completed
Fusion of pronuclei and zygote formation
Questions.explanation:
Characteristics of Fertilization include
	 â€¢ Cortical granule enzymes digest ZP proteins so other sperm can no longer bind. 
	 Hyaluronic acid and other proteoglycans are also released that become hydrated and swell, thus pushing the other sperm away. 
	 Meiosis II is completed 
	 The male and female pronuclei are formed 
	 Decondensation of male chromosomes 
	 Fusion of pronuclei and zygote formatio

Questions.question: which of these is a feature in compaction of embryo during cleavage?
options: Caused by increased cell-cell adhesion
Cells that are forced to the outside of the morula are destined to become trophoblast
Cells that are forced to the outside of the morula are destined to become epiblast
The inner cells will form the embryo proper
The embryo is already out of the Zona pellucida
Questions.explanation:
features in Compaction of the embryo include 
	 Caused by increase cell-cell adhesion 
	 cells that are forced to the outside of the morula are destined to become trophoblast cell that will form placenta
	 The inner cells will form the embryo proper and are call the inner cell mass or embryoblast

Questions.question: Which of these is not an avenue to screen for congenital birth defects
options: Ultrasound
Chorionic villi sampling
Ammiocentesis
All of the above
None of the above
Questions.explanation:
Screening for congenital defect can be done using 
	 ultrasound 
	 chorionic villi sampling 
	 Amniocentesis

Questions.question: All of the following are structural abnormalities associated with chromosome except
options: Cri-du-char syndrome
Angelman syndrome
Turner syndrome
Klinefelter syndrome
Prader-Willi syndrome
Questions.explanation:
Chromosomal abnormalities can be structural or numerical abnormalities
 NUMERICAL abnormalities include 
	 Down syndrom or Trisomy 21(extra copy of chromosome 21) 
	  Trisomy 18 or Edward syndrome(3 18th chromosomes) 
	 Trisomy 13 
	 45, X(Turner syndrome)
	 47,XXY (Klinefelter syndrome 
	 47,XYY
	 47,XXX(Tripple X syndrome)
 STRUCTURAL abnormalities include 
	 Prader-Willi
	 Angelman
	 Cri-du-char syndrome

Questions.question: A monozygotic twin where separation takes place just after the first cellular divison(1st three days) is characterised by the following
options: Each of the twins will have its own placenta
Each of the twins will have its own ammiotic sac
Each of the twins will share a common placenta
Each of the twins will share a common ammiotic sac
None of the above

Questions.question: which of the following are true concerning the cardiovascular system?
options: It begins development in the 3rd week
It is already funtional in the 4th week
Cells forming the heark are mesodermal in origin
It is highly regulated molecularly
All of the above

Questions.question: Which of these are true concerning the development of the heart layers?
options: The primordial myocardium begins to form from the splanchnic mesoderm
The primordial myocardium originates from the primitive ventricle
The endothelial tube becomes the endocardium, the innermost layer of the heart
Epicardium, originates from the mesothelial cells from the outer surface of the truncus arteriosus
Epicardium, originates from mesothelial cells from the outer surface of the bulbus cordis

Questions.question: Which of the following is a derivative of the sinus venosus?
options: The posterior portion of the right atrium
The chordae tendinea
The SA node
The fossa ovalis
The coronary sinus

Questions.question: The following are true of the aortic arches except
options: The first aortic arch regresses early, but a remnant forms a portion of the maxillary artery
The second aortic arch regresses early, but a remnant forms portions of the hyoid and stapedial arteries
The third arch regresses completely
The fourth arch gives rise to bilateral structures
All of the above

Questions.question: Which of these are correct concerning ectopia cordis
options: It is a very rare congenital condition
It can never be corrected
It could result to in abnormal development of the sternum
It is a common condition
Infants could die shortly after birth

Questions.question: Which of theses structures allow shunting of blood in the developing heart
options: Foramen ovale
Foramen arteriosus
Ductus arteriosus
Foramen venosum
All of the above

Questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning the ductus venosus?
options: It forms in the liver
It connects the left umbilical vein with the inferior vena cava
It connects the right umbilical vein with the infeior vena cava
The ductus serves as a bypas through the liver
It forms in the heart

Questions.question: Which of these is a feature in Tetralogy of Fallot?
options: Pulmonary infundibular stenosis
Atrial septa defect
An overriding aorta
Right ventricular hypertrophy
Left ventricular hypertrophy

Questions.question: Which of the following is correct about the normal fetal circulation?
options: Shunting of blood is as a result of higher pressure in the left chamber of the heart
Shunting of blood is as a result of higher pressure in the right chamber of the heart
Blood bypass the lungs through the ductus arteriosus
Ductus arteriosus sends oxygen rich blood to other parts of the body
The brain receives the blood with most oxygen

Questions.question: Which of these is true concerning Dextrocardia?
options: It is a common congenital condition
The apex of the heart is located on the right side of the body
It could occur with situs inversus
It could occur with a defect in the heart chambers
All of the above

Questions.question: The following is true about the placenta
options: Is a fetomaternal organ
The fetal portion develops from the endometrium
The maternal portion develops from the chorionic sac
Is a fetopaternal organ
It not the primary site of nutrient and gaseous exchange between the mother and fetus

Questions.question: The placenta
options: Develops upon implantaion of the blastocyst into the maternal endometrium
Is disc shaped
Is connected by the umbilical cord to the fetus
Helps in the transportation of gases and nutrients
Has a fetal and paternal part

Questions.question: The umbilical cord
options: Is approximately 60-70cm in length
Is approximately 55-60cm in length
Contains two umbilical veins and one umbilical artery
Contains two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein
Contains one umbilical artery, one umbilical vein and one umbilical nerve

Questions.question: The placenta has the following functions except
options: Metabolism
Excretion
Reproductive
Barrier Function
Transportation of gases and nutrients

Questions.question: The pleuroperitoneal membranes
options: By the 6th week grows to separated the pleural cavities
Separates the pericardial cavity from the pleural cavities
Separates the pleural cavities
Separates the pericardioperitoneal canals
By the 4th week grows to separate the pleural cavities form the pericardial cavity

Questions.question: The peritoneal cavity
options: Forms the major part of the intra-embryonic coelom(cavity)
Loses its connection with the extra-embryonic coelom by the 10th week of development, as the intestines return to the abdomen form the umbilical cord
Does not form the major part of the intra-embryonic coelom(cavity)
Forms major part of the extra-embryonic coelom(cavity)
Is connected with the extra-embryonic coelom at the umbilicus

Questions.question: The diaphragm is derived from the following structures except
options: The septum transversum
The pleuropericadial membranes
The pleuroperitoneal membranes
Dorsal mesentery of the esophagus
Muscular ingrowth from the medial body walls

Questions.question: Septum Transversum
options: Is first visible by the end of the 3rd as a mass of mesodermal tissue
Forms the primordium of the central tendon of the diaphragm
Forms a thick partition between the pericardial and abdominal cavity by the 4th week
Forms a complete partition between the pericardial and abdominal cavity by the 4th week
None of the above

Questions.question: Pleuroperitoneal membranes
options: Completely separated the thoracic and abdominal cavities
Fuses with the septum transversum and dorsal mesentery of the esophagus to completely sepatates the thoracic and abdominal cavities
Forms a major part of the early fetal diaphragm
Forms a major part of the adult diaphragm
All of the above

Questions.question: Dorsal mesentery of the esophagus
options: Fuses with the septum transversum to complete partition between the thoracic and abdominal cavities
Fuses with the pleuroperitoneal membranes to completely separate the thoracic and abdominal cavities
Is not involved in the formation of the diaphragm
Forms the median portion of the diaphragm
None of the above

Questions.question: The following are True concerning Epithelial tissue except
options: Are tissues in which cells are bound tightly together structurally and functionally
They are tissues that form a sheet like or tubular structure with little extracellulary material between cells
The cells in their epithelia each have apical side facing the sheeps free surface and a basal side
The cells in their Epithelia have a basal side facing a basement membrane and underlying connective tissue
Their epithelia are oftem specialized for absorption or transcytosis or pinocytosis of material

Questions.question: Concerning the Basement membrane of all epithelia the following is/are False
options: It is a thin extracellular layer of specialized proteins
It usually has twoo parts, a basal lamina and a fibrous reticular lamina
Their basal lamina is a thin meshwork of type IV collagen and lamina produces by the epithelial cell
Their reticular lamina contains type III collagen and anchoring fibers of VII collagen all served by cells of the immediately adjacent connective tissue
None of the above

Questions.question: Concerning the intercellular Junction
options: They are well developed in epithelia and consist of 3 major types with different functions
The tight intercellular junction is also called the occluding junction
The occluding junctions are formed by interacting trans membrane protein such as claudin and occludin
The linear arrangement of claudin and occluding surround the apical ends of the cells there by preventing paracellular passage of substance between cells
Intercellular junction play a crucial role in transmembrane permeability

Questions.question: The following statements are FALSE
options: Adherent or anchoring junctions is formed by interacting proteins of cadhering family which are points of strong attachment holding together cells of the epithelium
Adherent junction may form zonular adherence that encircle epithelial cells just below their tight junction
Zonula adherence are scattered spot like attachments site called desmosomes or maculae adherens
Hemidesmosomes composed of transmembrane integrins attach cells to proteins of the basal lamina
Gap junction are also called communicating junction are points of cell contact where both plasma membranes have numerous hexametric complexes transmembrane connexion

Questions.question: Concerning the Apical Structure of Epithelial cells
options: Microvilli are small membrane projections with cores of actin filaments that generally function to increase epithelia cell's apical surface area for absorption
Stereocilia are long microvilli with specialized mechanosensory function in cells of the inner ear and for absorption in tissues of the male reproduction tract
Cilia are larger projecting structure with a well-organized core of microtubules in a 9 + 2 arrangement called the axonema
The restricted, dynein-based sliding of microtubules causes ciliary movement that propel material along an epithelia surface
The Apical structure of epithelia cells possess several mechanisms for locomotion and a medium for interphasing of tissue

Questions.question: The following statement are TRUE
options: An epithelium in which the basement membrane has one cell layer is simple
The cells of different simple epithelia vary in height to form very thin or squamous to roughly cuboidal to very tall or columnar
The epithelia with two or more layers of cells are stratified squamous in which the outer cell layer are thin and flat
Cells of stratified squamous epithelia are filled with keratin intermediate filaments
All of the above

Questions.question: TRUE/FALSE
options: Pseudostratified epithelia are thick and appear to have several cell layers; all cells attach to the basal lamina but not all extend to the free epithelial surface
Squamous stratified epithelia such as the epidermis cover the body surface, protecting underlying tissue from the excess water loss and microbial invasion
Transitional epithelium or urothelium as found in the lining of the urinary system is stratified, with large round surface cell protective against urine
Simple squamous epithelia cells are found in the Alveolar sac

Questions.question: About the Gland
options: Exocrine glands produce mucus or similar individual cells called goblet cells which are called mucous gland
The oligosaccharide components of mucus stain poorly with routine dye but stain well with PAS stain
Exocrine glands producing largely enzyme(proteins) are called serous glands and stain darkly with H & E due to the cells content of RER and secretary granules
The secretory proteins of exocrine gland may form round, sac like acine(alveoli) or elongated tubules; both types of secretory unit may themselves branch
Glands have 3 basic secretory mechanisms which are either merocrine, Holocrine or Apocrine

Questions.question: TRUE/FALSE
options: Adipocytes are cells specialized for storage of triglyceride, they predominate in a specialized form of connective tissue called Adipose tissue
Connective tissue is specialized to physical support and connect other tissue and maintain the water required for metabolic diffusion to and from cells
Connective tissue all consist primarily of extracellular material rather than cells
The ECM of connective tissue proper usually consist of both large protein tube and non-fibrous are of unstained ground substance rich in various GAGs and water
All adult connective tissues are derived from an embryonic form of connective tissue called the mesenchyme

Questions.question: Concerning the fibres of connective tissue
options: The most important and abundant fibers of connective tissue are composed of the protein collagen of which there are some 20 related type
Fibrils of type I collagen are bundled together by other forms of non-fibrillar, linking collagens to produce large collagen bundles
Collagen fibrils are degraded by collagenase enzyme
Collagenase enzyme is classified as a matrix metalloproteinase(MMPs) which is produced primarily by macrophages
All of the above options are true

Questions.question: Concerning the Ground substance
options: The ground substance is the watery, largely unstained extracellular material that is more abundant than
Ground substance is rich in hydrated glycosaminoglycan, proteoglycans and multiadhesive glycoproteins
Chondrointin sulfate are examples of sulfated GAGs
Sulfated GAGs are all bonds to core proteins of proteoglycans and are produced in the golgi apparatus before secretion
Fibronectin and laminin are example of multiadhesive glycoprotein

Questions.question: Concerning connective Tissue
options: Connective tissue proper is usually classified as loose or dense according to the amount of collagen and ground substance presents
Loose connective tissue has relative more ground substance than collagen and its is typically surrounded by small blood vessels and occupy adjacent areas to other types of epithelia
Dense irregular connective tissue is filled primarily with randomly distributed bundles of type I collagen with some elastic fibers
Dense irregular connective tissue has more resistance to tearing from all directions as well as some elasticity
Reticular tissue consists of delicate networks of type III collagen (reticulin) and is most abundant in certain lymphoid organ

Questions.question: TRUE/FALSE
options: White adipose tissue is found in many organs throughout the body
White adipose tissue typically form about 20% of the body weight in adults
Adipocyte of white fat are typically very large cells ranging in diameter from 50-150mm
These cells each contain primarily one large lipid droplet(they are unilocular). Causing the nucleus and remaining cytoplasm to be pushed against the plasmalemma
Fatty acids are released from white adipocyte when nutrients are needed and carried throughout the body on plasma protein such as albumin

Questions.question: Striated Muscle
options: Consist of mainly two types
Are capable of relatively fast contractions
Are always under voluntary control
Has a poorly organized contractile apparatus
Are found in the walls of the alimentary tract

Questions.question: The units of Skeletal muscle are the
options: Muscle fibres
The A bands
The I bands
The Z bands

Questions.question: The following are true concerning skeletal muscles
options: The fibers are arranged in bundles also known as fascisculus
The endomysium is the connective tissue sheath that fills the spaces between the fasciculi
Each fasciculus is also surrounded by a stronger connective tissue, the perimysium
The whole muslce is covered by epimysium
The epimysium is continuous with the perimysium

Questions.question: In longitudinal sections
options: The myofibrils are not tranversed by striations
The myofibrils do not vary in their staining reactions nor do they vary in optical properties
I-bands or isotropic bands stain lightly with basic dyes and rotate the plane of polarization of light
The anisotropic A bands stain deeply with haematoxylin and strongly rotate the plane of polarization of light
The Zwischenscheibe or Z bands bisect the I bands

Questions.question: Electron microscopy shows skeletal muscle to be
options: Composed of longitudinally disposed fine myofilaments
The myofilaments are divided transversely by the Z bands
The division form repeating regions called sarcomeres
The myofilaments are Actin and Myosin
The Actin filaments are attached at one end to a Z-band

Questions.question: The myosin filaments
options: Interdigitate with the Actin filaments
Do not overlap with the acin filaments at the I bands
Are coextensive with the A bands of light microscopy
Have fine strands that interconnect adjacent myosin filaments viz the M bands that lie transversely across the middle of the H bands
In contracted state have slide in relation to the Actin filaments bringing the Z bands closer together

Questions.question: Each myosin filament
options: Has a tail, neck and head
The tail is made of light mero myosin
The head is made up of heavy mero myosin
Is arranged in parallel bundles
The myosin head bears two sites for spliting ATP, stimulated by the presence of calcium ions

Questions.question: Excitation contraction coupling
options: Involves the manner in which energy is converted to mechanical movement
Is aided by the activity of troponin and tropomyosin
Is aided by the release of calcium ions
Is aided by the sarcoplasm of muscle fibres
Is aided by the presence of ribosomes

Questions.question: The following are essential for normal muscle action
options: Golgi bodies
Lysosomes
Lipid vacuoles
Glycogen
Cell membranes

Questions.question: The following is true concerning innervation of skeletal muscles
options: The nerves may be one or more entering the neuromucular hilum and contains both motor and sensory fibres
The motor fibres comprise myelinated efferents of ventral grey column motor neurons(alpha efferents) supplying extra-fusal muscle fibers
The smaller myelinated gamma efferents run to the muscle spindle and non-myelinated autonomic efferents which supply vascular smooth muscles
The  sensory fibres are distributed to the muscle spindles
Once the nerve has entered the muscle, it breaks up into a plexus which runs in the Epi and perimysial septa then endomysial spaces

Questions.question: Gap Junctions of epithelial cells can be likened to
options: Nexuses of cardiac muscle cells
Solar plexus
Arachnoid granulations
Neuromuscular junctions
Communicating junctions

Questions.question: Communicating junctions in cardiac muscles
options: Are made of intercalated disc and desmosomes
Permit the relatively unimpeded flow of ionic current
Are of great importance in the dissemination of contractions within the heart
Allow excitation and contraction in one part of a muscle to spread to all cells of the bundle
Allow the heart to behave electrically as a syncytium

Questions.question: In anatomical position
options: The head is directed forward
The gaze is directed upwards
The toes are directed laterally
The arms are adjacent to the sides of the body
The palm faces medially

Questions.question: About anatomical planes
options: The median plane divides the body into right and left halves
The sagittal plane is perpendicular to the median plane
The coronal plane is parallel to the median plane
The transverse plane is perpendicular to the median plane
The transverse is perpendicular to the coronal plane

Questions.question: About movement
options: Flexion decreases the angle
Adduction is moving away from the median plane
Pronation occurs in the leg
Eversion moves the palm of the hand away from the median plane
Opposition occurs in the toes

Questions.question: Clavipectoral fascia
options: Encloses pectoralis minor
Encloses clavicle
Is pierced by lateral pectoral nerve
Is pierced by basilic vein
Is pierced by thoracoacromial artery

Questions.question: Select the correct matches of branches of brachial plexus with their roots
options: Nerve to serratus anterior (C5-C7)
Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)
Ulnar nerve (C7,C8,T1)
Radial nerve (C5-C8,T1)
Dorsal scapular nerve (C5-C7)

Questions.question: The branches of the lower trunk of brachial plexus include
options: Nerve to subclavius
Suprascapular nerve
Dorsal subscapular nerve
Upper subscapular nerve
Lower subscapular nerve

Questions.question: Pick the correct statement about Erb's paralysis
options: Occurs at the upper trunk
Arm is abducted
Arm is medially rotated
Forearm is flexed
Forearm is pronated

Questions.question: The cervicoaxillary canal is bounded
options: Medially by lateral border of first rib
Laterally by the surgical neck of the humerus
Anteriorly by the anterior border of the clavicle
Posteriorly by the superior border of the scapula
Inferiorly the axillary fascia

Questions.question: Which of the following contribute to anastomosis on the subscapular fossa?
options: Dorsal scapular artery
Suprascapular artery
Subscapular artery
Circumflex scapular artery
Posterior circumflex humeral artery

Questions.question: About arterial anastomoses around the elbow
options: Posterior ulnar collateral anastomoses with superior ulnar recurrent
Anterior ulnar collateral anastomoses with inferior ulnar recurrent
Superior radial collateral anastomoses with posterior radial recurrent
Inferior radial collateral anastomoses with anterior radial recurrent
Interosseous collateral anastomoses with interosseous recurrent

Questions.question: The following is incorrect about the elbow joint except
options: It is a hinge type of synovial joint
The capitulum articulates with the trochlea
Head of radius articulates with olecranon fossa
It is continuous with superior radioulnar joint
It allows abduction-adduction movement

Questions.question: Which of the following is correct about carrying angle?
options: Transverse axis of the elbow joint is directed medially and downwards
The medial flange of the trochlea is lower than the lateral flange
The superior articular surface of the coronoid process of ulna is oblique
It disappears in full flexion
It disappear during pronation

Questions.question: The contents of the Upper triangular space include the following except
options: Circumflex scapular artery
Dorsal Scapular artery
Suprascapular artery
Thoracoacromial artery
Lateral thoracic artery

Questions.question: The contents of the quadrangular space include
options: Radial artery
anterior circumflex humeral artery
Posterior circumflex humeral artery
Radial nerve
Axillary nerve

Questions.question: Lymph from the breast drain into
options: Anterior group axillary lymph nodes
Parasternal node
Supraclavicular node
Cephalic nodes
Posterior intercostal nodes

Questions.question: Concerning fascial spaces, the following statement(s) is/are correct
options: They are also known as tissue spaces
They are potential spaces that exist between the fasciae and underlying organs
In health fascial spaces do not exist
They are of no relevance in oral and maxillofacial surgery
All of the above

Questions.question: The muscles of the hypothenar eminence include
options: Palmaris brevis
Pronator teres
Anconeus
Supinator
Extensor digiti minimi

Questions.question: Failure to revascularise the scaphoid in the event of a fracture can lead to
options: Avascular necrosis
Rheumatism
Future arthritis
Osteoporsis
All of the above

Questions.question: The following statement(s) is/are correct concerning the palmar arches
options: The superficial palmar arch is more distally located than the deep palmar arch
The deep palmar arch branches out into smaller arteries that serve the fingers
The superficial palmar arch lies further away from the thumb than the deep palmar arch
The palm arch is either deep or superficial loops of blood vessels in the palm of the hand
All of the above

Questions.question: The following statement(s) is/are correct concerning the flexor retinaculum
options: It is also known as the longitudinal carpal ligament
It is located at the dorsal aspect of the wrist
It is a triangular shaped fibrous band
On the radial side it is attached to the scaphoid tubercle
It forms the floor of the carpal tunnel

Questions.question: Concerning the Carpal Tunnel syndrome the following statement(s) is are correct except
options: The tissues in the carpal tunnel are inflamed
One of the tendons in the Carpal tunnel is fibrotic
Pressure is exerted on the median nerve
It is the most commonly reported nerve entrapment syndrome
Obesity and rheumatoid arthritis are particularly high risk factors

Questions.question: The Carpus is composed of the following carpal bones except
options: Trapezium
Cubiod
Cuneiform
Capitate
Navicular

Questions.question: Functions of the palmer aponeurosis include the the following except
options: Protects underlying structures
Provides attachment to muscles
Provides firm attachment to overlying skin
Provides palmar creases
Helps to form the ridges in the palm

Questions.question: The following statements is/are correct concerning the palmar crease
options: The distal transverse palmar crease runs along the top of the palm
The proximal transverse palmar crease is above the distal crease
The thenar transverse palmar crease runs vertically around the base of the thumb
A & C only
All of the above

Questions.question: The Thenar musculature consist of the following muscles except
options: Abductor policis brevis
Adductor pollicis
Flexor pollicis brevis
Opponens pollicis
Palmaris longus

Questions.question: The bony surfaces that form the KNEE JOINT include the foollowing EXCEPT
options: The smooth surfaces of the condyles of the femur, Tibia and patella
The distal surfaces of the condyles of the femur, Tibia and patella
The smooth surfaces of the condyles of the femur, fibula and tibia
The distal surfaces of the condyles of the patella, fibula and femur

Questions.question: The capsule of the HIP is attached proximally to
options: The margins of the acetabulum
The Transverse acetabular ligament
The Trochanteric line
The bases of the lesser and greater Trochanters
Femoral neck

Questions.question: Which of the following ligament(s) remains intact in posterior dislocation of the Hip joint
options: Ilioinguinal ligament
Ligament of Bigelow
Pubofemoral ligament
Ischiofemoral ligament
Acetabular ligament

Questions.question: When one foot is off the ground, dropping of the pelvis to the unsupported side is prevented by
options: Gluteus minimus
Tensor Fascia latae
Gluteus maximus
Tibialis anterior
Ligamentum teres

Questions.question: The following is/are TRUE about the cutaneous supply the lower limb
options: L4 supplies the front medial aspect of the leg
S1 supplies the lateral side of the foot only
S2 supplies the posterior surface of the leg and thigh
S3 only supplies the buttock and perineal region
S3 only supplies the posterior part of the Scrotum

Questions.question: The following is/are correct about the ILIOTIBIAL TRACT
options: It is a thin fascia lata on the anterior side of the thigh
It encloses the fascia lata superiorly
Major part of the gluteus maximus is inserted into it
The tract is inserted into GERDY'S tubercle
It maintains the knee in the hyperextended position

Questions.question: The following is/are incorrect about the SUBSARTORIAL CANAL
options: Lies between the vastus lateralis and anterior aspect of adductor muscles
Its content include femoral artery and nerve to Vastus medialis
Its floor contains the adductor longus and magnus
Femoral vein is posterolateral to the artery in the canal distally
Femoral vein is posterolateral to the artery in the canal medially

Questions.question: The following is/ar TRUE about the Piriformis muscle EXCEPT
options: Relevant in the arrangements of the structures in the gluteal region
The surface marking of the lower border is from the midpoint of a line between the postero-superior iliac spine
It is innervated by anterior rami of S1 and S2
It is innervated by posterior rami of S2 and S3
It is inserted into medial surface of the upper border of the greater trochanter

Questions.question: About the SCIATIC NERVE the following is/are INCORRECT
options: It may be demaged during intramuscular injection
It runs vertically through the hamstrings compartment
Its surface marking is from the midpoint between the ischial tuberosity and the greater trochanter to the apex of the popliteal fossa
Its lies deep to the long head of the biceps
It divides into tibial and common peroneal nerve at the base of the popliteal fossa

Questions.question: The following is/are TRUE about the PATELLA
options: It articulates with the two femoral condyles posteriorly
It has a larger medial facet and a smaller lateral facet laterally
Lateral displacement is usually resisted by the lateral femoral condyles
Recurrent dislocation of the patella may occur in Genu Valgum
Its lateral displacement is usually resisted by the medial pull of vastus medialis

Questions.question: The following is/are correct about HIP DISLOCATION
options: It is usually posterior in flexed position
There may not be acetabular fracture if the hip is in adducted position
In abducted position, there may be fracture of the posterior acetabular lip
The sciatic nerve may be compromised
Central dislocation may result from a fall from a height

Questions.question: The following is/are True about the KNEE JOINT EXCEPT
options: Its Capsule is reinforced on each side by the medial and lateral collateral ligament
Its Capsule is strengthened anteriorly by the ligamentum patellae
Its capsule is strengthened on each side by the patella
The cruciate ligaments connect the tibia with the femur
It is majorly stabilized by Quadriceps femoris

Questions.question: The following is/are INCORRECT about the Leg
options: The muscles of the lateral compartment are innervated by the musculocutaneus nerve
The posterior compartment muscle are long extensor muscles of the sole of the foot
The muscles of the flexor compartment are supplied by the fibular nerve
The anterior compartment muscles are long extensor muscles of the toe
The extensor compartment is innervated by deep peroneal nerve

Questions.question: Obturator nerve supply the following except
options: Obturator externus
Gracilis
Adductor magnus
Adductor longus
All of the above

Questions.question: Obturator nerve supply the following
options: Hip joint
Knee joint
Area of the skin over the lateral aspect of the thigh
Adductor longus
None of the above

Questions.question: In the groin, the femoral artery gives of the following except
options: Superficial circumflex iliac artery
Superficial epigastric artery
Deep internal pudendal artery
Superficial iliac artery
All of the above

Questions.question: Eversion of the foot is the duty of the following except
options: Peroneus longus
Peroneus intermedius
Peroneus anterior
peroneus brevis
None of the above

Questions.question: Inversion of the foot is the duty of the following Except
options: Tibialis posterior
Tibialis anterior
Tibialis intermedius
Peroneus brevis
All of the above

Questions.question: The arches of the foot are maintained by the following except
options: Short ligament
Long ligament
Spring ligament
All of the above
None of the above

Questions.question: The Principal muscle concerned in the mechanism of arches of the foot include the following except
options: Tibialis posterior
Tibialis anterior
Peroneus brevis
Peroneus intermedius
None of the above

Questions.question: The lateral arch of the foot comprises of the following bones except
options: Calcaneus
Cubiod
Talus
Navicular
All of the above

Questions.question: The medial arch of the foot comprises of the following bones except
options: Calcaneus
Cubiod
Talus
Navicular
All of the above

Questions.question: The following muscle are the principal dorsiflexors of the ankle except
options: Tibialis posterior
Tibialis anterior
Flexor Hallucis longus
Flexor Hallucis brevis
All of the above

options: Flexor digitorum longus
Flexor Hallucis longus
Flexor Hallucis brevis
Tibialis anterior

First degree potts fracture
Third degree potts fracture
Non fracture of the lateral malleoli
